channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Karlijn Keijzer and Quinn Schansman Were Aboard Malaysia Airlines Flight 17
item.description: Karlijn Keijzer, 25, and Quinn Schansman, 19, were on their way to vacations when the Malaysia Airlines jet was brought down.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID MONTGOMERY and IAN LOVETT

item.title: Downing of Jet Exposes Defects of Flight Precautions Over Ukraine
item.description: Flight restrictions underestimated the risks to a startling degree, leaving Flight 17 exposed at 33,000 feet to missiles known to fly to more than twice that height.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER, C. J. CHIVERS and NICOLA CLARK
item.media:description: Liow Tiong Lai, Malaysia’s transport minister, said that the aircraft shot down over Ukraine had been following a safe route.

item.title: Hamas Tunnels Prompted Invasion of Gaza
item.description: Gaza militants have long used tunnels to attack Israel. A recent incursion led to the discovery of dozens, the Israeli military said.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Israeli Defense Forces, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: The Israeli military displayed weapons near Sufa where it said it destroyed a tunnel that militants used to enter the country.

item.title: Conviction of Berlusconi in Sex Case Is Overturned
item.description: An appeals court acquitted the former Italian prime minister of paying for sex with a minor and revoked his seven-year sentence and ban from public office.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: The former Italian prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, on Friday.

item.title: Negotiators Agree to Extend Iran Nuclear Talks Four More Months, Diplomats Say
item.description: Iran, the United States and five other countries agreed to a four-month extension as they try to bridge a divide over whether Iran must dismantle parts of its nuclear program, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: World Briefing: Argentina: Pope Calls for Justice
item.description: Pope Francis called for justice to be served in the deadly bombing of a Jewish community center in Buenos Aires 20 years ago that local courts have blamed on Iran.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Fleeing Amid Airstrikes, Gazans Find Few Places to Be Safe
item.description: For civilians in the Gaza Strip, the hardships of war include a lack of electricity and clean water.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: An Israeli bomb exploded in Gaza City Friday evening, less than 24 hours after Israeli tanks rolled into the northern Gaza Strip.

item.title: Quick History: A Week of Agony, From Eastern Ukraine to the Gaza Strip
item.description: There are times when the endless crises and conflicts of our times reach such paroxysms of senseless tragedy that the world cries out for a halt.
item.dc:creator: By SERGE SCHMEMANN
item.media:description: Tanks maneuvered outside the northern Gaza Strip on Friday, as Israel intensified its land offensive against Hamas, with artillery, tanks and gunboats.

item.title: With Grief on Top of Grief, Malaysians Are Tested on Flight 370’s Lessons
item.description: Anger over Malaysia Airline’s decision to fly the Ukraine route could prove a new challenge for the government four months after another plane operated by the carrier disappeared.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Women at Kuala Lumpur International Airport on Friday mourning a relative who was among the 298 passengers and crew aboard Malaysia Airlines Flight 17.

item.title: Rebels in Ukraine Crowed of Past Attacks, but Deny This One
item.description: As investigators look into who shot down a Malaysia Airlines jet, the rebels in Ukraine have been using increasingly powerful weapons against hard-to-reach targets
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Alexander Borodai, a separatist official, center, at a site where the airliner came down. He says the rebels do not have the technical means to have shot it down.

item.title: A Mother Asks Obama: ‘Please Remember My Amir’
item.description: The letter from Behnaz Hekmati, the mother of Amir Hekmati, appeared timed to convey the family’s wish that the United States use its leverage in the talks to win his release.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: The Netherlands, a Nation in Mourning but Mindful of Ties to Russia
item.description: For the Dutch, the prospect that Russian-backed separatists might be responsible for the loss of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 poses a dilemma.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Rutte of the Netherlands. “We have no exact information on what caused the disaster,” he said.

item.title: U.S. Sees Evidence of Russian Links to Jet’s Downing
item.description: President Obama pointed to the Kremlin’s role in arming rebels in the area of the attack and referred to the events there as an “outrage of unspeakable proportions.”
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER, MICHAEL R. GORDON and MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: News Analysis: A Push Into Gaza, but the Ground Has Shifted
item.description: The landscape differs from previous battles with Hamas, largely because Israel has framed its operations as an effort to eliminate tunnels used to store weapons or stage attacks.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers carried their gear toward a staging area outside the Gaza Strip on Friday. Two Israelis and more than 280 Palestinians had died in the fighting.

item.title: ISIS Forces Last Iraqi Christians to Flee Mosul
item.description: An era of tolerance for different religions appeared to have come to an abrupt end as minority sects sought sanctuary from militants in Christian enclaves.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Iraqis attending Mass in June at a church in Al Qosh, where many Christians have fled after being intimidated into leaving their homes in Mosul.

item.title: World Briefing: Germany: An Unusually Large Exodus From the Roman Catholic Church
item.description: After an uproar over a bishop’s lavish new $42 million residence, more than 178,000 Germans left the church in 2013, the German Bishops’ Conference said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Syria: Scores Killed in Clash as Jihadis Seize a Gas Field
item.description: Islamic extremists killed at least 115 Syrian troops, guards and workers while capturing a gas field in central Syria after a long day of clashes. More than 20 insurgents also died in the fighting.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Ethiopia: Bloggers and Journalists Are Charged as Terrorists
item.description: Three Ethiopian journalists and six bloggers were charged with planning terrorist attacks during a court hearing in Addis Ababa on Friday morning, nearly three months after they were arrested.
item.dc:creator: By JACEY FORTIN

item.title: World Briefing: Myanmar: Wrong Message Is Being Sent About Free Speech, U.S. Says
item.description: The United States has said it is “very concerned” by reports that four journalists and their newspaper’s chief executive had been sentenced to 10 years of hard labor.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Pakistan: More Attacks on Soldiers and the Police in Tribal Regions
item.description: An attack by militants on a security checkpoint in Jamrud killed eight soldiers. Four of the militants also died.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Needing Skilled Workers, a Booming Germany Woos Immigrants
item.description: The country is competing more aggressively with the United States, Britain and other nations to attract and keep educated people from abroad.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Opinion: ‘Protecting’ Russians in Ukraine Has Fatal Consequences
item.description: The right to protect one’s “people” — where does it end? In blood.
item.dc:creator: By TIMOTHY GARTON ASH
item.media:description: A man examined debris on Friday from the Malaysia Airlines crash a day earlier, in a field in Grabovo, Ukraine.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Tibetan Leader, a Red Sox Fan, Knows the Value of Taking the Long View
item.description: Lobsang Sangay, Tibet’s prime minister in exile, has learned to draw strength from unfulfilled aspirations as he faces criticism and meager prospects for autonomy.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: "There is this unfulfilled desire, unfulfilled aspiration," said Prime Minister Lobsang Sangay. "That keeps you going."

item.title: Opinion: The Independence Referendum Is a Test of Scotland’s Confidence
item.description: Whether or not Scots opt for independence in September, the referendum will have changed perceptions of what’s possible.
item.dc:creator: By NEAL ASCHERSON
item.media:description: The Union Jack flag waved near Stirling Castle on February 3, 2014 in Stirling, Scotland.

item.title: Bulgaria Says DNA Shows Man Bombed Bus in 2012
item.description: The authorities said a French-Lebanese man was part of a group responsible for the blast, which killed seven people, including five Israeli tourists.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY and GEORGI KANTCHEV
item.media:description: The tour bus that was destroyed by a bomb in July 2012 at Bourgas Airport in Bulgaria.
